newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - April 14.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - April 14.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Monday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- KwaZulu Natal premier Ben Ngubane had become exbroiled in conflict with other parties following his decision to cut the budget of the transport department, headed by African National Congress (ANC) provincial deputy chairman Sibusiso Ndebele - but to allocate funds in his own department for the building of roads.

- South African companies tendering for all state contracts with an imported content exceeding 22 million rand will, like overseas counterparts, be required to set up a separate business as part of government's attempt to generate economic benefits for the local economy, says the trade and industry department.

- The potential buyers of state-owned forestry group Safcol will have to contend with high operating costs, partly due to wage rates which are at least 40 percent higher than the private sector, and an overstaffed workforce.

- The African National Congress (ANC) has committed itself to consulting with its alliance partners in a bid to bridge the gap which has widened in recent months, especially after the adoption of government's growth, employment and redistribution strategy (Gear).

- Plessey will sell the branded division of its low-margin consumer electronic arm, Tek Corporation, to Omega Holdings for between 50 million rand and 70 million rand, John Temple, the chief executive of Plessey, said on Friday.

- Pyramid Mining and Exploration, a subsidiary of listed Canadian mining group AfriOre, could embark on a mining project worth billions of rands off the KwaZulu Natal coast, it was disclosed last week.

- Mathomo, a niche retailer and wholesaler with a focus on sporting goods and branded clothing, has diversified into stationery with the 24.6 million rand acquisition of Tonclin Investment Holdings, the holding company of the Eldons Stationery group.

- Alec Erwin, the trand and industry minister, has sacked his appointees tasked with drafting competition legislation and will select a new team to draft legislation for tabling in parliament early next year.
- Four heavily armed gangs have been identified as being responsible for the majority of robberies plaguing Johannesburg financial institutions since the beginning of the year.
- A motorist who was hijacked in his white BMW by a fleeing bank robber after a shoootout in Randburg on Saturday is alive and well.

- A major financial institution is set to pump thousands of rands in to the upgrading of Soweto's biggest tourist attraction, a "Struggle Village", where the houses of freedom fighters President Nelson Mandela, Walter Sisulu, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, Archbishop Desmond Tutu and the grave of 1976 riot victim Hector Peterson are situated.
